raw_extractions.description: Qian Qichen served as the Foreign Minister of China and was involved in diplomatic interactions with U.S. counterparts.
supporting_quotes: Qian spends a considerable portion of his book recounting interactions with his U.S. counterparts during his term as foreign minister
Scowcrofts belief that China got cold feet after the fall of Ceausescu in Romania (in late December) was incorrect. It was Washington, Qian insists, that reevaluated the strategic situation

raw_extractions.description: Qian Qichen engaged in diplomatic discussions and visits to Washington, including a notable interaction with Brent Scowcroft.
supporting_quotes: noting that he and Scowcroft shared a hearty laugh about the toast during one of Qians later visits to Washington.

raw_extractions.description: Qian Qichen worked within the U.N. context to craft a resolution regarding Iraq's withdrawal from Kuwait.
supporting_quotes: China had been working cooperatively within the U.N. context to try to craft a resolution that would bring about Iraqs voluntary withdrawal from Kuwait

raw_extractions.description: Qian Qichen received a phone call from U.S. Secretary of State James Baker regarding a potential deal on the U.N. resolution on Iraq.
supporting_quotes: A bit more than a week before the vote was to take place (November 20, 1990), Baker (who was in Paris) called Qian with a deal.

raw_extractions.description: China abstained from the Security Council vote on the resolution regarding Iraq on November 28, 1990.
supporting_quotes: Thinking he had Qians agreement, Baker was angered when China abstained from the Security Council vote on November 28, 1990

raw_extractions.description: Qian Qichen was involved in talks with U.S. Secretary of State James Baker during Baker's visit to Beijing in November 1991.
supporting_quotes: Whether those feelings played a role in how Baker was treated on his visit to Beijing the following November, Qian does not say.

raw_extractions.description: Qian Qichen met with Warren Christopher at the Waldorf Astoria Hotel to discuss Taiwan President Lee Teng-hui's potential visit to the United States.
supporting_quotes: Qian describes his April 17, 1995, meeting with Christopher at the Waldorf Astoria Hotel in New York in brief terms.

When we spoke about Lee Teng-huis scheme to visit the United States, Christopher pledged clearly that the United States would not permit Lee to visit America, and said that a Lee visit to America was not consistent with the unofficial character of Americas relations with Taiwan; at most, they were considering giving Lee an extended transit visa.

raw_extractions.description: Qian Qichen was involved in managing the crisis in U.S.-China relations following the issuance of a visa to Lee Teng-hui.
supporting_quotes: That visa was issued on May 22, 1995, precipitating a serious crisis in U.S. -China relations, which Qian describes in detail.
When the foreign minister of a superpower makes a promise externally, then unexpectedly goes back on his word, that cannot help but cause people to feel shock and indignation.
Ten Stories of a Diplomat makes no claim to being a complete history, much less an autobiography, and thus leaves many questions unanswered, many stories incomplete.
